contentChunks.htmlValue:
Contents

Key colors
Tonal palettes

The color system handles the variability of dynamically changing color schemes that arise as user inputs change. The logic of tonal relationships and shifts in hue and chroma provide a foundation for flexible color application. Color schemes can be considered a cohesive group of relative tones, rather than a fixed group of constant values.
Key colors

contentChunks.altText: Three accent colors, and two desaturated neutral colors.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
The foundation of a color scheme is the set of five key colors that individually relate to separate tonal palettes with 13 tones. Specific tones from each tonal palette are assigned to color roles across a UI. 

Key colors are the foundation for creating any dynamic color scheme. With key colors established, Material’s algorithm specifies the full spectrum of colors needed for expressing interaction states, errors, and accessible contrast.  

Custom colors can be added to a scheme as well. Learn more about custom colors.
Key colors: accent & neutral

Accent colors

The primary key color is used to derive roles for key components across the UI, such as the FAB, prominent buttons, active states, as well as the tint of elevated surfaces.

The secondary key color is used for less prominent components in the UI such as filter chips, while expanding the opportunity for color expression.

The tertiary key color is used to derive the roles of contrasting accents that can be used to balance primary and secondary colors or bring heightened attention to an element. The tertiary color role is left for teams to use at their discretion and is intended to support broader color expression in products.

contentChunks.altText: Primary, secondary, and tertiary colors and their contrasting accents colors.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Neutral colors

The neutral key color is used to derive the roles of surface and background, as well as high emphasis text and icons.

The neutral variant key color is used to derive medium emphasis text and icons, surface variants, and component outlines.

contentChunks.altText: Neutral key color and neutral variant key color and their contrasting accent colors.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Additional colors

Error colors

In addition to the accent and neutral key color, the color system includes a semantic color role for error, again in the form of the error role itself, plus an on-error, error container, and on-error container role.

contentChunks.altText: A red color assigned as error and contrasting accent colors.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Product-specific custom colors

Custom colors pin specific hues that often are needed alongside expressive colors in UI as a way to communicate conventional meaning, such as errors.

They’re also used to give teams more control and customization alongside the variability of a dynamic color environment.

contentChunks.altText: An app with orange, green, and red icons set to fixed colors, and UI elements assigned to dynamic user colors.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Tonal palettes

contentChunks.footer: The 100 tone is always 100% white, the lightest tone in the range; the 0 tone is 100% black, the darkest tone in the range.
contentChunks.altText: A gradient demonstrating the range of tones from 1 (black) to 100 (white)

contentChunks.htmlValue:
One key color becomes thirteen tones

A tonal palette consists of thirteen tones, including white and black. A tone value of 100 is equivalent to the idea of light at its maximum and results in white. Every tone value between 0 and 100 expresses the amount of light present in the color.

contentChunks.footer: The tonal value of each color is expressed with the number associated with that role, e.g. primary40 is the primary key color at a tone value of 40.
contentChunks.altText: 13 tones derived from a key color.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Contents

Roles in a scheme
Mapping accent roles
Mapping neutral roles

Color schemes

While key colors are the basis for tonal palettes, only a selection of the 13 colors from each tonal palette are used in a UI. A scheme is the group of tones assigned to specific roles that get mapped to components.

A primary color’s tonal palette, for example, defines tones for paired roles such as the colors for text and icons that are placed on top of a component (on primary). The tone pairings in color roles provide accessible contrast by default and inform tone adjustments for any additional custom color to work harmoniously with an existing scheme.
Roles in a scheme

contentChunks.altText: A primary key color and its accent colors

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Each accent color (primary, secondary, and tertiary) is provided in a group of four compatible colors of different tones for pairing, defining emphasis, and visual expression. 

Accent colors: Primary, secondary, and tertiary roles are formed following the same pattern of a 4-color group. 

Primary is used here as an example:

  • Primary base color 
  • On-primary is applied to content (icons, text, etc.) that sits on top of primary
  • Primary container is applied to elements needing less emphasis than primary
  • On-primary container is applied to content (icons, text, etc.) that sits on top of primary container

Neutral roles are used for surfaces and backgrounds, as well as high emphasis text and icons.

By mapping and coding roles through tokens, rather than assigning hex values, a color can update systematically if a color palette changes. Tokens enable changes to a role's color value to cascade consistently.

contentChunks.footer: From five key colors, roles are automatically assigned roles that map to light theme components.
contentChunks.altText: A color diagram that shows how one color is extrapolated into a 4-color group that includes 3 additional and derived tones.

contentChunks.htmlValue: When a color scheme is generated, the tonal palettes include mappings for a dark theme as well. Apps receive light and dark tones through a single generated scheme.

contentChunks.footer: From five key colors, roles are automatically assigned roles that map to dark theme components.
contentChunks.altText: A dark theme color diagram that shows how one color is extrapolated into a 4-color group that includes 3 additional and derived tones.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Mapping accent roles
The examples below demonstrate how roles are applied.
Primary
Primary roles are used for key components across the UI, such as the FAB, prominent buttons, active states, as well as the tint of elevated surfaces.

contentChunks.altText: Color swatches: primary, on primary, primary container  and on primary container

contentChunks.footer: 1. On-primary 2. Primary
contentChunks.altText: Primary color used for filled button, and "on primary" color used for the text within that button

contentChunks.footer: 3. On-primary container 4. Primary container
contentChunks.altText: "Primary container" color used for FAB and "on primary container" color used for the text and icon within.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Secondary
Secondary roles are used for less prominent components in the UI, such as filter chips, while expanding the opportunity for color expression.

contentChunks.altText: Color swatches: secondary, on secondary, secondary container, and on secondary container

contentChunks.footer: 1. Icon: On secondary container 2. Secondary container
contentChunks.altText: An icon button using "secondary container" color, and an icon using "on secondary color."

contentChunks.htmlValue: Tertiary

Tertiary roles are used for contrasting accents that can be used to balance primary and secondary colors or bring heightened attention to an element, such as an input field. 

The tertiary color role is left for makers to use at their discretion and is intended to support broader color expression in products.

contentChunks.altText: Four color swatches: tertiary, on tertiary, tertiary container, and on tertiary container
A selected element using Tertiary Container as a background color and On Tertiary Container for text.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Mapping neutral roles: background & surfaces
Neutral
Neutral roles are used for surfaces and backgrounds, as well as high emphasis text and icons.

contentChunks.altText: Four color swatches: background, on background, surface, and on surface

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Surface tones

While background color remains consistent, surface color is not static.

Surfaces at elevation levels +1 to +5 are tinted via color overlays based on the primary color, such as app bars or menus. The addition of a grade from +1 to +5 introduces tonal variation to the surface baseline.

Tonal surfaces provide a few benefits:

  • Simulate the effect of elevation to create differentiation amongst competing content areas
  • Establish contrast for accessibility benefits
  • Create visual interest and soften transitions between interactive elements

contentChunks.footer:
1. Surface
2. Content layer
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of a transparent content layer over a surface layer.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Surface 1

At elevation +1 components with surface color containers receive a primary color overlay with 5% opacity.

contentChunks.altText: A dialog box with elevation +1

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Surface 2

At elevation +2 components with surface color containers receive a primary color overlay with 8% opacity.

contentChunks.altText: Title and action bars with elevation +2

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Surface 3

At elevation +3 components with surface color containers receive a primary color overlay with 11% opacity.

contentChunks.altText: FABs and dialog box with elevation +3

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Surface at 4 and 5

At elevation +4, components with surface color containers receive a primary color overlay with 12% opacity.

At elevation +5 (not illustrated), components with surface color containers receive a primary color overlay with 14% opacity.

contentChunks.altText: A FAB with elevation +4

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Inverse roles

These additional role mappings exist in a scheme and are mapped to components where needed.

contentChunks.altText: Three swatches: Inverse surface, on inverse surface, and inverse primary

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Inverse surface

Inverse surface and inverse on surface are used for displaying the reverse of what’s seen in the surrounding UI. 

For example, snackbars use the reverse color mapping to bring attention to an alert.

contentChunks.altText: Anatomy diagram of a dialog using inverse colors

contentChunks.htmlValue: Neutral variant
Surface variant and on-surface variant can be used for differentiation against a surface

contentChunks.altText: Three swatches: surface variant, on surface variant, and outline.

contentChunks.footer:
1. On surface variant
2. Surface variant
contentChunks.altText: Anatomy diagram showing use of surface variant colors

contentChunks.footer: 1. Outline

contentChunks.htmlValue: Outline
Outline is a utility color that creates boundaries and emphasis to improve usability. The outline color has a 3:1 contrast with all surface colors.

contentChunks.footer: Use the outline color for accessible boundaries around interactive items such as chips, buttons, and text fields.
Don’t use the outline color for components that contain multiple elements, such as cards. Instead, use the outline variant color.
Don’t use the outline color for dividers since they have different contrast requirements. Instead, use the outline variant color.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Outline variant
Outline variant is a utility color that creates boundaries for decorative elements when a 3:1 contrast isn’t required, such as for dividers or decorative elements.

contentChunks.footer: Use the outline variant color for decorative boundary elements like dividers.

Don’t use the outline variant color for clustered elements like chips, or other UI elements that are in close proximity to each other. Instead, use outline or another color providing 3:1 contrast with the surface color.
Don’t use the outline variant color to create visual hierarchy or define the visual boundary of targets. Instead, use the outline color or another color providing 3:1 contrast with the surface color.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Baseline color scheme tokens

The M3 baseline color scheme uses the same roles and token mapping as user-generated color schemes. For full details on working with color roles, see the applying color schemes section.

Jump to the tokens table.

contentChunks.footer: Material baseline colors applied throughout a UI and components. With the baseline color roles as a starting point for color mapping, apps can use dynamic color.
contentChunks.altText: Baseline color palette applied to various UI components

contentChunks.footer: The M3 baseline color scheme uses a purple primary color and complementary accent colors that follow the logic of a custom theme's tonal relationships.
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of 5 different colors: 3 accent colors in the purple family and 2 neutral colors in shades of grey.

contentChunks.htmlValue: The baseline colors translate to groups of related tones. The tones are mapped to roles that create contrast and visual interest when applied to elements in the UI.

contentChunks.altText: Full palette derived from baseline colors

contentChunks.htmlValue: The same tonal palettes created from M3 baseline's five key colors also produce the colors to comprise a dark scheme.

contentChunks.altText: Dark palette derived from baseline colors

contentChunks.htmlValue: Baseline color scheme tokens

Adding custom colors to a scheme

Colors in a scheme are primarily the result of your key colors and their complementary generated tones. Custom colors undergo the same treatment as the core scheme, enabling you to input a custom key color that automatically gets assigned a set of complementary tones.

contentChunks.footer: Inputting a key color generates tones for custom color roles.
contentChunks.altText: Custom colors and their derivative accent colors

contentChunks.htmlValue: In the diagram below, yellow, orange, and green are custom color inputs. A custom color input is translated into tones to automatically provide the range of tones that map to color roles.

contentChunks.footer: Examples of custom colors that can be added and translated into a group of four compatible tones that would be used for role mapping in a custom light scheme.
contentChunks.altText: Different custom colors and the resulting accent colors

contentChunks.htmlValue: In total, core scheme colors and custom colors comprise your entire scheme. You can choose which colors from the resulting scheme that you want to apply.

contentChunks.footer: Left: Core scheme colors from M3 baseline light scheme; Right: Examples of custom color inputs that comprise the custom colors in a scheme.
contentChunks.altText: Core scheme color palette alongside custom colors

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Harmonization

Harmonization makes adding and introducing new colors to your app more seamless by automatically shifting hue and chroma slightly so that a product's colors feel more cohesive with user colors
Apply custom colors using the same color roles and relationships that you would use when applying a core scheme.

contentChunks.footer: Content and On Content color roles are used for these buttons and the green tone shows a harmonized color output.
contentChunks.altText: Buttons using content and on content color roles and custom colors

contentChunks.footer: Container and On Container color roles used for cards.
contentChunks.altText: Cards using custom colors and container and on container color roles

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Product-specific custom colors

Custom colors pin specific hues that often are needed alongside expressive colors in UI as a way to communicate conventional meaning, such as errors.

They’re also used to give teams more control and customization alongside the variability of a dynamic color environment.

contentChunks.altText: An example UI using a combination of user and custom colors in different palettes

contentChunks.htmlValue: The Material Theme Builder will include a color harmonization feature that can shift tones of a custom color to ensure that visual balance and accessible contrast is achieved when combined with user-generated colors.

contentChunks.footer: Custom colors (1) are assessed against a user's source color (2) that defines their personal scheme. The result is a harmonized variation (3) on the original color tones that allows both inputs to combine in a UI successfully
contentChunks.altText: Diagram showing how a user-set input results in a harmonized color and its accents

contentChunks.footer: Material offers color harmonization to avoid creating dissonant color schemes when custom colors pair with user colors.
contentChunks.altText: Three user colors and a harmonized color scheme

contentChunks.footer: Harmonization makes adding new colors to your app more seamless by ensuring they adapt to user colors, shifting hues slightly to feel more at home in the overall scheme.
contentChunks.altText: shifting colors resulting in a harmonized color scheme

contentChunks.htmlValue: Color & accessibility

Dynamic color is designed to meet accessibility standards for color contrast. Material's system based on tonal palettes is central to making color schemes that are accessible by default. 

Combining color based on tonality, rather than hex values or hues, is one primary method that Material ensures color outputs are accessible by default. The color algorithm is designed so that the potential combinations a user will experience are meeting the standards for contrast.

Contrast

Contrast describes the amount of perceived difference between two colors. Color plays a part in an interface's visual accessibility by ensuring contrast between elements so that two things of similar color are differentiated. 

Sufficient contrast between two colors, such as button text and a button container, is an essential piece of visual accessibility because optimizes usability for a broad range of human vision and experience.

contentChunks.footer: The ‘Accept’ button achieves sufficient contrast for visual accessibility, while the ‘Ignore’ button does not.

contentChunks.htmlValue: For accessibility measures, the degree of contrast is measured and represented as a ratio.  Contrast ratios measure the difference in lightness or darkness between two colors. A high ratio indicates greater difference between colors and therefore indicates higher contrast.

contentChunks.footer: These two colors create a high amount of contrast. They have a contrast ratio of 7.72:1.
These two colors create a low amount of contrast. They have a contrast ratio of 1.35:1.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Contrast in Material

Material's color system provides standard tone values and measurements that can be used to meet accessible contrast ratios.

Material's tonal system corresponds to Web color contrast standards as follows:

  • Colors that are at least 40 steps apart in tonal value achieve a contrast ratio of at least 3:1
  • Colors that are at least 50 steps apart in tonal value achieve a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1
  • Colors that are at least 70 steps apart in tonal value achieve a contrast ratio of at least 7:1

Contrast ratios vary

Specific elements and their intended application will determine which level of contrast is necessary for a given element.

Accessible defaults

By default, Material components, such as buttons, are designed to meet contrast requirements for visual accessibility.

The contrast ratio remains fixed when a dynamic color scheme changes or switches from a light to dark theme.

contentChunks.footer: Material components are designed to achieve sufficient contrast by default.
Dynamic color retains sufficient contrast regardless of the color scheme.

contentChunks.htmlValue: By default, Material color roles that are paired and often applied together are also designed to meet contrast requirements for visual accessibility.

contentChunks.footer: Color roles that are designed to be applied together achieve sufficient contrast by default.
Dynamic color retains sufficient contrast regardless of the color scheme.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Non-text elements

Some non-text elements, such as button containers, should meet a contrast ratio of 3:1 for standard accessibility (graded as AA). Learn more about non-text elements and principles for applying color in accessibility patterns.

Large text

Large text (18pts or larger, or 14pts or larger if bold) should meet a contrast ratio of 3:1 for standard accessibility (graded as AA) and 4.5:1 for greater accessibility (graded as AAA).

Standard text sizes

Standard body text sizes (smaller than 18pts, or smaller than 14pts if bold) should meet a contrast ratio of 4.5:1 for standard accessibility (graded as AA) and 7:1 for greater accessibility (graded as AAA).
